metadata.title: Ensure /tmp is configured
metadata.description:
Since the /tmp directory is intended to be world-writable, there is a risk of resource exhaustion if it is not bound to a separate partition. Running out of /tmp space is a problem regardless of what kind of filesystem lies under it, but in a default installation a disk-based /tmp will essentially have the whole disk available, as it only creates a single / partition. On the other hand, a RAM-based /tmp as with tmpfs will almost certainly be much smaller, which can lead to applications filling up the filesystem much more easily.
/tmp utalizing tmpfs can be resized using the size={size} parameter on the Options line on the tmp.mount file

reference.source: CIS Ubuntu Linux 18.04 LTS Benchmark V2.0.1

metadata.title: Ensure nodev option set on /tmp partition
metadata.description: The nodev mount option specifies that the filesystem cannot contain special devices.

reference.source: CIS Ubuntu Linux 18.04 LTS Benchmark V2.0.1

metadata.title: Ensure nosuid option set on /tmp partition
metadata.description: Since the /tmp filesystem is only intended for temporary file storage, set this option to ensure that users cannot create setuid files in /tmp .

reference.source: CIS Ubuntu Linux 18.04 LTS Benchmark V2.0.1

metadata.title: Ensure noexec option set on /tmp partition
metadata.description: Since the /tmp filesystem is only intended for temporary file storage, set this option to ensure that users cannot run executable binaries from /tmp .

reference.source: CIS Ubuntu Linux 18.04 LTS Benchmark V2.0.1

metadata.title: Ensure separate partition exists for /var
metadata.description: Since the /var directory may contain world-writable files and directories, there is a risk of resource exhaustion if it is not bound to a separate partition.

reference.source: CIS Ubuntu Linux 18.04 LTS Benchmark V2.0.1

metadata.title: Ensure separate partition exists for /var/tmp
metadata.description: Since the /var/tmp directory is intended to be world-writable, there is a risk of resource exhaustion if it is not bound to a separate partition. In addition, making /var/tmp its own file system allows an administrator to set the noexec option on the mount, making /var/tmp useless for an attacker to install executable code. It would also prevent an attacker from establishing a hardlink to a system setuid program and wait for it to be updated. Once the program was updated, the hardlink would be broken and the attacker would have his own copy of the program. If the program happened to have a security vulnerability, the attacker could continue to exploit the known flaw.

reference.source: CIS Ubuntu Linux 18.04 LTS Benchmark V2.0.1

metadata.title: Ensure nodev option set on /var/tmp partition
metadata.description: Since the /var/tmp filesystem is not intended to support devices, set this option to ensure that users cannot attempt to create block or character special devices in /var/tmp .

reference.source: CIS Ubuntu Linux 18.04 LTS Benchmark V2.0.1

metadata.title: Ensure nosuid option set on /var/tmp partition
metadata.description: Since the /var/tmp filesystem is only intended for temporary file storage, set this option to ensure that users cannot create setuid files in /var/tmp .

reference.source: CIS Ubuntu Linux 18.04 LTS Benchmark V2.0.1

metadata.title: Ensure noexec option set on /var/tmp partition
metadata.description: Since the /var/tmp filesystem is only intended for temporary file storage, set this option to ensure that users cannot run executable binaries from /var/tmp .

reference.source: CIS Ubuntu Linux 18.04 LTS Benchmark V2.0.1

metadata.title: Ensure separate partition exists for /var/log
metadata.description: protection against resource exhaustion (since logs can grow quite large) and protection of audit data.

metadata.title: Ensure separate partition exists for /home

metadata.title: Ensure sudo is installed
metadata.description: sudo supports a plugin architecture for security policies and input/output logging. Third parties can develop and distribute their own policy and I/O logging plugins to work seamlessly with the sudo front end. The default security policy is sudoers, which is configured via the file /etc/sudoers. The security policy determines what privileges, if any, a user has to run sudo. The policy may require that users authenticate themselves with a password or another authentication mechanism. If authentication is required, sudo will exit if the user's password is not entered within a configurable time limit. This limit is policy-specific.

reference.source: CIS Ubuntu Linux 18.04 LTS Benchmark V2.0.1

metadata.title: Ensure sudo commands use pty
metadata.description: Attackers can run a malicious program using sudo, which would again fork a background process that remains even when the main program has finished executing.

reference.source: CIS Ubuntu Linux 18.04 LTS Benchmark V2.0.1

criterion.comment: /etc/sudoers.d/* config to only run other commands from a pseudo-pty

metadata.title: Ensure IP forwarding is disabled
metadata.description: The net.ipv4.ip_forward flag is used to tell the system whether it can forward packets or not.

reference.source: CIS Ubuntu Linux 18.04 LTS Benchmark V2.0.1

metadata.title: Ensure source routed packets are not accepted
metadata.description: Setting net.ipv4.conf.all.accept_source_route, net.ipv4.conf.default.accept_source_route, net.ipv6.conf.all.accept_source_route and net.ipv6.conf.default.accept_source_route to 0 disables the system from accepting source routed packets. Assume this system was capable of routing packets to Internet routable addresses on one interface and private addresses on another interface. Assume that the private addresses were not routable to the Internet routable addresses and vice versa. Under normal routing circumstances, an attacker from the Internet routable addresses could not use the system as a way to reach the private address systems. If, however, source routed packets were allowed, they could be used to gain access to the private address systems as the route could be specified, rather than rely on routing protocols that did not allow this routing.

reference.source: CIS Ubuntu Linux 18.04 LTS Benchmark V2.0.1

criterion.comment: all IPv4 source routed packets are not accepted
default IPv4 source routed packets are not accepted
all IPv6 source routed packets are not accepted
default IPv6 source routed packets are not accepted

metadata.title: Ensure ICMP redirects are not accepted
metadata.description: ICMP redirect messages are packets that convey routing information and tell your host (acting as a router) to send packets via an alternate path. It is a way of allowing an outside routing device to update your system routing tables. By setting net.ipv4.conf.all.accept_redirects to 0, the system will not accept any ICMP redirect messages, and therefore, won't allow outsiders to update the system's routing tables.

reference.source: CIS Ubuntu Linux 18.04 LTS Benchmark V2.0.1

criterion.comment: all IPv4 ICMP redirects are not accepted
default IPv4 ICMP redirects are not accepted
all IPv6 ICMP redirects are not accepted
default IPv6 ICMP redirects are not accepted

metadata.title: Ensure secure ICMP redirects are not accepted
metadata.description: Secure ICMP redirects are the same as ICMP redirects, except they come from gateways listed on the default gateway list.

reference.source: CIS Ubuntu Linux 18.04 LTS Benchmark V2.0.1

criterion.comment: all secure ICMP redirects are not accepted

metadata.title: Ensure broadcast ICMP requests are ignored
metadata.description: Setting net.ipv4.icmp_echo_ignore_broadcasts to 1 will cause the system to ignore all ICMP echo and timestamp requests to broadcast and multicast addresses.

reference.source: CIS Ubuntu Linux 18.04 LTS Benchmark V2.0.1

metadata.title: Ensure bogus ICMP responses are ignored
metadata.description: Setting icmp_ignore_bogus_error_responses to 1 prevents the kernel from logging bogus responses (RFC-1122 non-compliant) from broadcast reframes, keeping file systems from filling up with useless log messages.

reference.source: CIS Ubuntu Linux 18.04 LTS Benchmark V2.0.1

metadata.title: Ensure Reverse Path Filtering is enabled
metadata.description: Setting net.ipv4.conf.all.rp_filter and net.ipv4.conf.default.rp_filter to 1 forces the Linux kernel to utilize reverse path filtering on a received packet to determine if the packet was valid. Essentially, with reverse path filtering, if the return packet does not go out the same interface that the corresponding source packet came from, the packet is dropped (and logged if log_martians is set).

reference.source: CIS Ubuntu Linux 18.04 LTS Benchmark V2.0.1

criterion.comment: all Reverse Path Filtering is enabled
default Reverse Path Filtering is enabled

metadata.title: Ensure TCP SYN Cookies is enabled
metadata.description: When tcp_syncookies is set, the kernel will handle TCP SYN packets normally until the half-open connection queue is full, at which time, the SYN cookie functionality kicks in. SYN cookies work by not using the SYN queue at all. Instead, the kernel simply replies to the SYN with a SYN|ACK, but will include a specially crafted TCP sequence number that encodes the source and destination IP address and port number and the time the packet was sent. A legitimate connection would send the ACK packet of the three way handshake with the specially crafted sequence number. This allows the system to verify that it has received a valid response to a SYN cookie and allow the connection, even though there is no corresponding SYN in the queue.

reference.source: CIS Ubuntu Linux 18.04 LTS Benchmark V2.0.1

metadata.title: Ensure IPv6 router advertisements are not accepted
metadata.description: This setting disables the system's ability to accept IPv6 router advertisements.

metadata.title: Ensure wireless interfaces are disabled
metadata.description: Wireless networking is used when wired networks are unavailable. Ubuntu contains a wireless tool kit to allow system administrators to configure and use wireless networks.

reference.source: CIS Ubuntu Linux 18.04 LTS Benchmark V2.0.1

metadata.title: Ensure auditd is installed
metadata.description: auditd is the userspace component to the Linux Auditing System. It's responsible for writing audit records to the disk

reference.source: CIS Ubuntu Linux 18.04 LTS Benchmark V2.0.1

metadata.title: Ensure auditd service is enabled
metadata.description: Turn on the auditd daemon to record system events.

reference.source: CIS Ubuntu Linux 18.04 LTS Benchmark V2.0.1

metadata.title: Ensure auditing for procresses that start prior to auditd is enabled
metadata.description: Configure grub so that processes that are capable of being audited can be audited even if they start up prior to auditd startup.

reference.source: CIS Ubuntu Linux 18.04 LTS Benchmark V2.0.1

metadata.title: Ensure audit_backlog_limit is sufficient
metadata.description: The backlog limit has a default setting of 64

reference.source: CIS Ubuntu Linux 18.04 LTS Benchmark V2.0.1

criterion.comment: grub config supports audit backlog limit

metadata.title: Ensure audit log storage size is configured
metadata.description: Configure the maximum size of the audit log file. Once the log reaches the maximum size, it will be rotated and a new log file will be started.

reference.source: CIS Ubuntu Linux 18.04 LTS Benchmark V2.0.1

metadata.title: Ensure audit logs are not automatically deleted
metadata.description: The max_log_file_action setting determines how to handle the audit log file reaching the max file size. A value of keep_logs will rotate the logs but never delete old logs.

reference.source: CIS Ubuntu Linux 18.04 LTS Benchmark V2.0.1

metadata.title: Ensure the system is disabled when audit logs are full
metadata.description: The auditd daemon can be configured to halt the system when the audit logs are full.

reference.source: CIS Ubuntu Linux 18.04 LTS Benchmark V2.0.1

metadata.title: Ensure events that modify date and time information are collected
metadata.description: Capture events where the system date and/or time has been modified. The parameters in this section are set to determine if the adjtimex (tune kernel clock), settimeofday (Set time, using timeval and timezone structures) stime (using seconds since 1/1/1970) or clock_settime (allows for the setting of several internal clocks and timers) system calls have been executed and always write an audit record to the /var/log/audit.log file upon exit, tagging the records with the identifier "time-change"

reference.source: CIS Ubuntu Linux 18.04 LTS Benchmark V2.0.1

metadata.title: Ensure events that modify user/group information are collected
metadata.description: Record events affecting the group , passwd (user IDs), shadow and gshadow (passwords) or /etc/security/opasswd (old passwords, based on remember parameter in the PAM configuration) files. The parameters in this section will watch the files to see if they have been opened for write or have had attribute changes (e.g. permissions) and tag them with the identifier "identity" in the audit log file.

reference.source: CIS Ubuntu Linux 18.04 LTS Benchmark V2.0.1

metadata.title: Ensure events that modify the system's network environment are collected
metadata.description: Record changes to network environment files or system calls. The below parameters monitor the sethostname (set the systems host name) or setdomainname (set the systems domainname) system calls, and write an audit event on system call exit. The other parameters monitor the /etc/issue and /etc/issue.net files (messages displayed pre- login), /etc/hosts (file containing host names and associated IP addresses) and /etc/network (directory containing network interface scripts and configurations) files.

reference.source: CIS Ubuntu Linux 18.04 LTS Benchmark V2.0.1

metadata.title: Ensure events that modify the system's Mandatory Access Controls are collected
metadata.description: Monitor SELinux/AppArmor mandatory access controls. The parameters below monitor any write access (potential additional, deletion or modification of files in the directory) or attribute changes to the /etc/selinux or /etc/apparmor and /etc/apparmor.d directories.

reference.source: CIS Ubuntu Linux 18.04 LTS Benchmark V2.0.1

metadata.title: Ensure login and logout events are collected
metadata.description: Monitor login and logout events. The parameters below track changes to files associated with login/logout events. The file /var/log/faillog tracks failed events from login. The file /var/log/lastlog maintain records of the last time a user successfully logged in. The file /var/log/tallylog maintains records of failures via the pam_tally2 module

reference.source: CIS Ubuntu Linux 18.04 LTS Benchmark V2.0.1

metadata.title: Ensure session initiation information is collected
metadata.description: Monitor session initiation events. The parameters in this section track changes to the files associated with session events. The file /var/run/utmp file tracks all currently logged in users. All audit records will be tagged with the identifier "session." The /var/log/wtmp file tracks logins, logouts, shutdown, and reboot events. The file /var/log/btmp keeps track of failed login attempts and can be read by entering the command /usr/bin/last -f /var/log/btmp . All audit records will be tagged with the identifier "logins."

reference.source: CIS Ubuntu Linux 18.04 LTS Benchmark V2.0.1

metadata.title: Ensure discretionary access control permission modification events are collected
metadata.description: Monitor changes to file permissions, attributes, ownership and group. The parameters in this section track changes for system calls that affect file permissions and attributes. The chmod , fchmod and fchmodat system calls affect the permissions associated with a file. The chown , fchown , fchownat and lchown system calls affect owner and group attributes on a file. The setxattr , lsetxattr , fsetxattr (set extended file attributes) and removexattr , lremovexattr , fremovexattr (remove extended file attributes) control extended file attributes. In all cases, an audit record will only be written for non-system user ids (auid >= 1000) and will ignore Daemon events (auid = 4294967295). All audit records will be tagged with the identifier "perm_mod."

reference.source: CIS Ubuntu Linux 18.04 LTS Benchmark V2.0.1

metadata.title: Ensure unsuccessful unauthorized file access attempts are collected
metadata.description: Monitor for unsuccessful attempts to access files. The parameters below are associated with system calls that control creation ( creat ), opening ( open , openat ) and truncation ( truncate , ftruncate ) of files. An audit log record will only be written if the user is a non- privileged user (auid > = 1000), is not a Daemon event (auid=4294967295) and if the system call returned EACCES (permission denied to the file) or EPERM (some other permanent error associated with the specific system call). All audit records will be tagged with the identifier "access."

reference.source: CIS Ubuntu Linux 18.04 LTS Benchmark V2.0.1

criterion.comment: collect audit events for 64-bit creat with EACCES
collect audit events for 64-bit creat with EPERM
collect audit events for 32-bit creat with EACCES
collect audit events for 32-bit creat with EPERM
collect audit events for 64-bit open with EACCES
collect audit events for 64-bit open with EPERM
collect audit events for 32-bit open with EACCES
collect audit events for 32-bit open with EPERM
collect audit events for 64-bit openat with EACCES
collect audit events for 64-bit openat with EPERM
collect audit events for 32-bit openat with EACCES
collect audit events for 32-bit openat with EPERM
collect audit events for 64-bit truncate with EACCES
collect audit events for 64-bit truncate with EPERM
collect audit events for 32-bit truncate with EACCES
collect audit events for 32-bit truncate with EPERM
collect audit events for 64-bit ftruncate with EACCES
collect audit events for 64-bit ftruncate with EPERM
collect audit events for 32-bit ftruncate with EACCES
collect audit events for 32-bit ftruncate with EPERM

metadata.title: Ensure use of privileged commands is collected
metadata.description: Monitor privileged programs (those that have the setuid and/or setgid bit set on execution) to determine if unprivileged users are running these commands.

reference.source: CIS Ubuntu Linux 18.04 LTS Benchmark V2.0.1

criterion.comment: number of privileged audit rules >= number of suid and sgid binaries

metadata.title: Ensure successful file system mounts are collected
metadata.description: Monitor the use of the mount system call. The mount (and umount ) system call controls the mounting and unmounting of file systems. The parameters below configure the system to create an audit record when the mount system call is used by a non-privileged user

reference.source: CIS Ubuntu Linux 18.04 LTS Benchmark V2.0.1

metadata.title: Ensure file deletion events by users are collected
metadata.description: Monitor the use of system calls associated with the deletion or renaming of files and file attributes. This configuration statement sets up monitoring for the unlink (remove a file), unlinkat (remove a file attribute), rename (rename a file) and renameat (rename a file attribute) system calls and tags them with the identifier "delete".

reference.source: CIS Ubuntu Linux 18.04 LTS Benchmark V2.0.1

criterion.comment: collect audit events for 64-bit unlink events
collect audit events for 32-bit unlink events
collect audit events for 64-bit unlinkat events
collect audit events for 32-bit unlinkat events
collect audit events for 64-bit rename events
collect audit events for 32-bit rename events
collect audit events for 64-bit renameat events
collect audit events for 32-bit renameat events

metadata.title: Ensure changes to system administration scope (sudoers) is collected
metadata.description: Monitor scope changes for system administrations. If the system has been properly configured to force system administrators to log in as themselves first and then use the sudo command to execute privileged commands, it is possible to monitor changes in scope. The file /etc/sudoers will be written to when the file or its attributes have changed. The audit records will be tagged with the identifier "scope."

reference.source: CIS Ubuntu Linux 18.04 LTS Benchmark V2.0.1

metadata.title: Ensure system administrator actions (sudolog) are collected
metadata.description: Monitor the sudo log file. If the system has been properly configured to disable the use of the su command and force all administrators to have to log in first and then use sudo to execute privileged commands, then all administrator commands will be logged to /var/log/sudo.log . Any time a command is executed, an audit event will be triggered as the /var/log/sudo.log file will be opened for write and the executed administration command will be written to the log.

reference.source: CIS Ubuntu Linux 18.04 LTS Benchmark V2.0.1

metadata.title: Ensure kernel module loading and unloading is collected
metadata.description: Monitor the loading and unloading of kernel modules. The programs insmod (install a kernel module), rmmod (remove a kernel module), and modprobe (a more sophisticated program to load and unload modules, as well as some other features) control loading and unloading of modules. The init_module (load a module) and delete_module (delete a module) system calls control loading and unloading of modules. Any execution of the loading and unloading module programs and system calls will trigger an audit record with an identifier of "modules".

reference.source: CIS Ubuntu Linux 18.04 LTS Benchmark V2.0.1

metadata.title: Ensure the audit configuration is immutable
metadata.description: Set system audit so that audit rules cannot be modified with auditctl. Setting the flag "-e 2" forces audit to be put in immutable mode. Audit changes can only be made on system reboot.

reference.source: CIS Ubuntu Linux 18.04 LTS Benchmark V2.0.1

metadata.title: rsyslog is installed

reference.source: CIS Ubuntu Linux 18.04 LTS Benchmark V2.0.1

metadata.title: Ensure rsyslog service is enabled
metadata.description: Once the rsyslog package is installed it needs to be activated.

reference.source: CIS Ubuntu Linux 18.04 LTS Benchmark V2.0.1

metadata.title: Ensure rsyslog default file permissions configured
metadata.description: rsyslog will create logfiles that do not already exist on the system. This setting controls what permissions will be applied to these newly created files

reference.source: CIS Ubuntu Linux 18.04 LTS Benchmark V2.0.1

criterion.comment: rsyslog default file permissions configured in /etc/rsyslog.conf and|or /etc/rsyslog.d/*

metadata.title: Ensure rsyslog is configured to send logs to a remote log host
metadata.description: The rsyslog utility supports the ability to send logs it gathers to a remote log host running syslogd(8) or to receive messages from remote hosts, reducing administrative overhead.

reference.source: CIS Ubuntu Linux 18.04 LTS Benchmark V2.0.1

criterion.comment: rsyslog is configured to send logs to a remote log host in /etc/rsyslog.conf and|or /etc/rsyslog.d/*

metadata.title: Ensure journald is configured to send logs to rsyslog
metadata.description: Data from journald may be stored in volatile memory or persisted locally on the server. Utilities exist to accept remote export of journald logs, however, use of the rsyslog service provides a consistent means of log collection and export.

reference.source: CIS Ubuntu Linux 18.04 LTS Benchmark V2.0.1

criterion.comment: journald is configured to send logs to rsyslog in /etc/systemd/journald.conf

metadata.title: Ensure journald is configured to compress large log files
metadata.description: The journald system includes the capability of compressing overly large files to avoid filling up the system with logs or making the logs unmanageably large.

reference.source: CIS Ubuntu Linux 18.04 LTS Benchmark V2.0.1

criterion.comment: journald is configured to compress logs in /etc/systemd/journald.conf

metadata.title: Ensure journald is configured to write logfiles to persistent disk
metadata.description: Data from journald may be stored in volatile memory or persisted locally on the server. Logs in memory will be lost upon a system reboot. By persisting logs to local disk on the server they are protected from loss.

reference.source: CIS Ubuntu Linux 18.04 LTS Benchmark V2.0.1

criterion.comment: journald is configured to write log files to persistent disks in /etc/systemd/journald.conf

metadata.title: Ensure permissions on all logfiles are configured
metadata.description: Log files stored in /var/log/ contain logged information from many services on the system, or on log hosts others as well.

reference.source: CIS Ubuntu Linux 18.04 LTS Benchmark V2.0.1

criterion.comment: permissions on all logfiles are configured

metadata.title: Ensure cron daemon is enabled
metadata.description: The cron daemon is used to execute batch jobs on the system

reference.source: CIS Ubuntu Linux 18.04 LTS Benchmark V2.0.1

metadata.title: Ensure permissions on /etc/crontab are configured
metadata.description: The /etc/crontab file is used by cron to control its own jobs. The commands in this item make sure that root is the user and group owner of the file and that only the owner can access the file.

reference.source: CIS Ubuntu Linux 18.04 LTS Benchmark V2.0.1

metadata.title: Ensure permissions on /etc/cron.hourly are configured
metadata.description: Granting write access to this directory for non-privileged users could provide them the means for gaining unauthorized elevated privileges. Granting read access to this directory could give an unprivileged user insight in how to gain elevated privileges or circumvent auditing controls.

reference.source: CIS Ubuntu Linux 18.04 LTS Benchmark V2.0.1

metadata.title: Ensure permissions on /etc/cron.daily are configured
metadata.description: Granting write access to this directory for non-privileged users could provide them the means for gaining unauthorized elevated privileges. Granting read access to this directory could give an unprivileged user insight in how to gain elevated privileges or circumvent auditing controls.

reference.source: CIS Ubuntu Linux 18.04 LTS Benchmark V2.0.1

metadata.title: Ensure permissions on /etc/cron.weekly are configured
metadata.description: Granting write access to this directory for non-privileged users could provide them the means for gaining unauthorized elevated privileges. Granting read access to this directory could give an unprivileged user insight in how to gain elevated privileges or circumvent auditing controls.

reference.source: CIS Ubuntu Linux 18.04 LTS Benchmark V2.0.1

metadata.title: Ensure permissions on /etc/cron.monthly are configured
metadata.description: Granting write access to this directory for non-privileged users could provide them the means for gaining unauthorized elevated privileges. Granting read access to this directory could give an unprivileged user insight in how to gain elevated privileges or circumvent auditing controls.

reference.source: CIS Ubuntu Linux 18.04 LTS Benchmark V2.0.1

metadata.title: Ensure permissions on /etc/cron.d are configured
metadata.description: The /etc/cron.d directory contains system cron jobs that need to run in a similar manner to the hourly, daily weekly and monthly jobs from /etc/crontab , but require more granular control as to when they run. The files in this directory cannot be manipulated by the crontab command, but are instead edited by system administrators using a text editor.

reference.source: CIS Ubuntu Linux 18.04 LTS Benchmark V2.0.1

metadata.title: Ensure at/cron is restricted to authorized users
metadata.description: On many systems, only the system administrator is authorized to schedule cron jobs. Using the cron.allow file to control who can run cron jobs enforces this policy. It is easier to manage an allow list than a deny list. In a deny list, you could potentially add a user ID to the system and forget to add it to the deny files.

reference.source: CIS Ubuntu Linux 18.04 LTS Benchmark V2.0.1

metadata.title: SSH daemon is installed
metadata.description: section 5.2 only applies if SSH daemon is installed on the system

reference.source: CIS Ubuntu Linux 18.04 LTS Benchmark V2.0.1

metadata.title: Ensure permissions on /etc/ssh/sshd_config are configured
metadata.description: The /etc/ssh/sshd_config file contains configuration specifications for sshd

reference.source: CIS Ubuntu Linux 18.04 LTS Benchmark V2.0.1

metadata.title: Ensure permissions on SSH private host key files are configured
metadata.description: An SSH private key is one of two files used in SSH public key authentication. In this authentication method, The possession of the private key is proof of identity. Only a private key that corresponds to a public key will be able to authenticate successfully. The private keys need to be stored and handled carefully, and no copies of the private key should be distributed.

reference.source: CIS Ubuntu Linux 18.04 LTS Benchmark V2.0.1

metadata.title: Ensure permissions on SSH public host key files are configured
metadata.description: An SSH public key is one of two files used in SSH public key authentication. In this authentication method, a public key is a key that can be used for verifying digital signatures generated using a corresponding private key. Only a public key that corresponds to a private key will be able to authenticate successfully.

reference.source: CIS Ubuntu Linux 18.04 LTS Benchmark V2.0.1

metadata.title: Ensure SSH Protocol is not set to 1
metadata.description: SSH supports two different and incompatible protocols: SSH1 and SSH2. SSH1 was the original protocol and was subject to security issues. SSH2 is more advanced and secure.

reference.source: CIS Ubuntu Linux 18.04 LTS Benchmark V2.0.1

criterion.comment: SSH protocol is not set to 1

metadata.title: Ensure SSH LogLevel is appropriate
metadata.description: INFO level is the basic level that only records login activity of SSH users. In\ many situations, such as Incident Response, it is important to determine when a particular user was active on a system. The logout record can eliminate those users who disconnected, which helps narrow the field. VERBOSE level specifies that login and logout activity as well as the key fingerprint for any SSH key used for login will be logged. This information is important for SSH key management, especially in legacy environments.

reference.source: CIS Ubuntu Linux 18.04 LTS Benchmark V2.0.1

criterion.comment: SSH LogLevel is set to INFO

metadata.title: Ensure SSH X11 forwarding is disabled
metadata.description: The X11Forwarding parameter provides the ability to tunnel X11 traffic through the connection to enable remote graphic connections.

reference.source: CIS Ubuntu Linux 18.04 LTS Benchmark V2.0.1

metadata.title: Ensure SSH MaxAuthTries is set to 4 or less
metadata.description: The MaxAuthTries parameter specifies the maximum number of authentication attempts permitted per connection. When the login failure count reaches half the number, error messages will be written to the syslog file detailing the login failure.

reference.source: CIS Ubuntu Linux 18.04 LTS Benchmark V2.0.1

criterion.comment: SSH MaxAuthTries is set to 4 or less

metadata.title: Ensure SSH IgnoreRhosts is enabled
metadata.description: The IgnoreRhosts parameter specifies that .rhosts and .shosts files will not be used in RhostsRSAAuthentication or HostbasedAuthentication .

reference.source: CIS Ubuntu Linux 18.04 LTS Benchmark V2.0.1

metadata.title: Ensure SSH HostbasedAuthentication is disabled
metadata.description: The HostbasedAuthentication parameter specifies if authentication is allowed through trusted hosts via the user of .rhosts , or /etc/hosts.equiv , along with successful public key client host authentication. This option only applies to SSH Protocol Version 2.

reference.source: CIS Ubuntu Linux 18.04 LTS Benchmark V2.0.1

metadata.title: Ensure SSH root login is disabled
metadata.description: The PermitRootLogin parameter specifies if the root user can log in using ssh(1). The default is no.

reference.source: CIS Ubuntu Linux 18.04 LTS Benchmark V2.0.1

metadata.title: Ensure SSH PermitEmptyPasswords is disabled
metadata.description: The PermitEmptyPasswords parameter specifies if the SSH server allows login to accounts with empty password strings.

reference.source: CIS Ubuntu Linux 18.04 LTS Benchmark V2.0.1

metadata.title: Ensure SSH PermitUserEnvironment is disabled
metadata.description: The PermitUserEnvironment option allows users to present environment options to the ssh daemon.

reference.source: CIS Ubuntu Linux 18.04 LTS Benchmark V2.0.1

metadata.title: Ensure only strong Ciphers are used
metadata.description: This variable limits the ciphers that SSH can use during communication.

reference.source: CIS Ubuntu Linux 18.04 LTS Benchmark V2.0.1

metadata.title: only approved MAC algorithms are used
metadata.description: Limits the types of MAC algorithms that SSH can use during communication.

reference.source: CIS Ubuntu Linux 18.04 LTS Benchmark V2.0.1

criterion.comment: only approved MAC algorithms are used

metadata.title: Ensure only strong Key Exchange algorithms are used
metadata.description: Key exchange is any method in cryptography by which cryptographic keys are exchanged between two parties, allowing use of a cryptographic algorithm. If the sender and receiver wish to exchange encrypted messages, each must be equipped to encrypt messages to be sent and decrypt messages received

reference.source: CIS Ubuntu Linux 18.04 LTS Benchmark V2.0.1

criterion.comment: only approved key exchanged algorithms are used

metadata.title: Ensure SSH Idle Timeout Interval is configured
metadata.description: The two options ClientAliveInterval and ClientAliveCountMax control the timeout of ssh sessions. When the ClientAliveInterval variable is set, ssh sessions that have no activity for the specified length of time are terminated. When the ClientAliveCountMax variable is set, sshd will send client alive messages at every ClientAliveInterval interval. When the number of consecutive client alive messages are sent with no response from the client, the ssh session is terminated. For example, if the ClientAliveInterval is set to 15 seconds and the ClientAliveCountMax is set to 3, the client ssh session will be terminated after 45 seconds of idle time.

reference.source: CIS Ubuntu Linux 18.04 LTS Benchmark V2.0.1

criterion.comment: ClientAliveCountMax is configured to be 3 or less

metadata.title: Ensure SSH LoginGraceTime is set to one minute or less
metadata.description: The LoginGraceTime parameter specifies the time allowed for successful authentication to the SSH server. The longer the Grace period is the more open unauthenticated connections can exist. Like other session controls in this session the Grace Period should be limited to appropriate organizational limits to ensure the service is available for needed access.

reference.source: CIS Ubuntu Linux 18.04 LTS Benchmark V2.0.1

criterion.comment: SSH LoginGraceTime is less than 60 seconds(1 minute)
SSH LoginGraceTime is greater than or equal to 1

metadata.title: Ensure SSH access is limited
metadata.description: The AllowUsers variable gives the system administrator the option of allowing specific users to ssh into the system. The list consists of comma separated user names. Numeric user IDs are not recognized with this variable. If a system administrator wants to restrict user access further by only allowing the allowed users to log in from a particular host, the entry can be specified in the form of user@host. AllowGroups The AllowGroups variable gives the system administrator the option of allowing specific groups of users to ssh into the system. The list consists of comma separated group names. Numeric group IDs are not recognized with this variable. DenyUsers The DenyUsers variable gives the system administrator the option of denying specific users to ssh into the system. The list consists of comma separated user names. Numeric user IDs are not recognized with this variable. If a system administrator wants to restrict user access further by specifically denying a user's access from a particular host, the entry can be specified in the form of user@host. DenyGroups The DenyGroups variable gives the system administrator the option of denying specific groups of users to ssh into the system. The list consists of comma separated group names. Numeric group IDs are not recognized with this variable.

reference.source: CIS Ubuntu Linux 18.04 LTS Benchmark V2.0.1

metadata.title: Ensure SSH warning banner is configured
metadata.description: The Banner parameter specifies a file whose contents must be sent to the remote user before authentication is permitted. By default, no banner is displayed.

reference.source: CIS Ubuntu Linux 18.04 LTS Benchmark V2.0.1

metadata.title: Ensure SSH PAM is enabled
metadata.description: UsePAM Enables the Pluggable Authentication Module interface. If set to yes this will enable PAM authentication using ChallengeResponseAuthentication and PasswordAuthentication in addition to PAM account and session module processing for all authentication types

reference.source: CIS Ubuntu Linux 18.04 LTS Benchmark V2.0.1

metadata.title: Ensure SSH AllowTcpForwarding is disabled
metadata.description: Leaving port forwarding enabled can expose the organization to security risks and back-doors. SSH connections are protected with strong encryption. This makes their contents invisible to most deployed network monitoring and traffic filtering solutions. This invisibility carries considerable risk potential if it is used for malicious purposes such as data exfiltration. Cybercriminals or malware could exploit SSH to hide their unauthorized communications, or to exfiltrate stolen data from the target network

reference.source: CIS Ubuntu Linux 18.04 LTS Benchmark V2.0.1

metadata.title: Ensure SSH MaxStartups is configured
metadata.description: The MaxStartups parameter specifies the maximum number of concurrent unauthenticated connections to the SSH daemon.

reference.source: CIS Ubuntu Linux 18.04 LTS Benchmark V2.0.1

metadata.title: Ensure SSH MaxSessions is set to 4 or less
metadata.description: The MaxSessions parameter specifies the maximum number of open sessions permitted from a given connection.

reference.source: CIS Ubuntu Linux 18.04 LTS Benchmark V2.0.1

criterion.comment: SSH MaxSessions is set in the range 1 to 4

metadata.title: Ensure password creation requirements are configured
metadata.description: Password creation requirements need to be configured

reference.source: CIS Ubuntu Linux 18.04 LTS Benchmark V2.0.1

metadata.title: Ensure lockout for failed password attempts is configured
metadata.description: Lock out users after n unsuccessful consecutive login attempts. The first sets of changes are made to the PAM configuration files. The second set of changes are applied to the program specific PAM configuration file. The second set of changes must be applied to each program that will lock out users. Check the documentation for each secondary program for instructions on how to configure them to work with PAM. Set the lockout number to the policy in effect at your site.

reference.source: CIS Ubuntu Linux 18.04 LTS Benchmark V2.0.1

metadata.title: Ensure password reuse is limited
metadata.description: Forcing users not to reuse their past 5 passwords make it less likely that an attacker will be able to guess the password. Note that these change only apply to accounts configured on the local system.

reference.source: CIS Ubuntu Linux 18.04 LTS Benchmark V2.0.1

metadata.title: Ensure password hashing algorithm is SHA-512
metadata.description: The SHA-512 algorithm provides much stronger hashing than MD5, thus providing additional protection to the system by increasing the level of effort for an attacker to successfully determine passwords. Note that these change only apply to accounts configured on the local system.

reference.source: CIS Ubuntu Linux 18.04 LTS Benchmark V2.0.1

metadata.title: Ensure password expiration is 365 days or less
metadata.description: Reducing the maximum age of a password reduces an attacker's window of opportunity.

reference.source: CIS Ubuntu Linux 18.04 LTS Benchmark V2.0.1

criterion.comment: all users with a password have their maximum days between password change set to 365 or less

metadata.title: Ensure minimum days between password changes is configured
metadata.description: By restricting the frequency of password changes, an administrator can prevent users from repeatedly changing their password in an attempt to circumvent password reuse controls.

reference.source: CIS Ubuntu Linux 18.04 LTS Benchmark V2.0.1

criterion.comment: all users with a password have their minimum days between password change set to 1 or more

metadata.title: Ensure password expiration warning days is 7 or more
metadata.description: Providing an advance warning that a password will be expiring gives users time to think of a secure password.

reference.source: CIS Ubuntu Linux 18.04 LTS Benchmark V2.0.1

criterion.comment: all users with a password have their number of days of warning before password expires set to 7 or more

metadata.title: Ensure inactive password lock is 30 days or less
metadata.description: Inactive accounts pose a threat to system security since the users are not logging in to notice failed login attempts or other anomalies.

reference.source: CIS Ubuntu Linux 18.04 LTS Benchmark V2.0.1

criterion.comment: inactive password lock is 30 days or less for users with a password

metadata.title: Ensure system accounts are secured
metadata.description: It is important to make sure that accounts that are not being used by regular users are prevented from being used to provide an interactive shell.

reference.source: CIS Ubuntu Linux 18.04 LTS Benchmark V2.0.1

criterion.comment: non-root system accounts have locked passwords

metadata.title: Ensure default group for the root account is GID 0
metadata.description: Using GID 0 for the root account helps prevent root-owned files from accidentally becoming accessible to non-privileged users.

reference.source: CIS Ubuntu Linux 18.04 LTS Benchmark V2.0.1

criterion.comment: default group for the root account is GID 0

metadata.title: Ensure default user umask is 027 or more restrictive
metadata.description: A default umask setting of 077 causes files and directories created by users to not be readable by any other user on the system. A umask of 027 would make files and directories readable by users in the same Unix group, while a umask of 022 would make files readable by every user on the system.

reference.source: CIS Ubuntu Linux 18.04 LTS Benchmark V2.0.1

criterion.comment: default user umask is set in /etc/bash.bashrc
default user umask is set in /etc/profile

metadata.title: Ensure default user shell timeout is 900 seconds or less
metadata.description: The default TMOUT determines the shell timeout for users. The TMOUT value is measured in seconds.

reference.source: CIS Ubuntu Linux 18.04 LTS Benchmark V2.0.1

criterion.comment: default user shell timeout is 900 seconds or less in /etc/bash.bashrc
default user shell timeout is 900 seconds or less in /etc/profile
default user shell timeout is 900 seconds or less in /etc/profile.d/*

metadata.title: Ensure access to the su command is restricted
metadata.description: By uncommenting the pam_wheel.so statement in /etc/pam.d/su , the su command will only allow users in a specific groups to execute su. This group should be empty to reinforce the use of sudo for privileged access.

reference.source: CIS Ubuntu Linux 18.04 LTS Benchmark V2.0.1

criterion.comment: pam_wheel with a group parameter is required
group referred in pam_wheel line is empty

metadata.title: Ensure permissions on /etc/passwd are configured
metadata.description: The /etc/passwd file contains user account information that is used by many system utilities and therefore must be readable for these utilities to operate.

reference.source: CIS Ubuntu Linux 18.04 LTS Benchmark V2.0.1

metadata.title: Ensure permissions on /etc/shadow are configured
metadata.description: The /etc/shadow file is used to store the information about user accounts that is critical to the security of those accounts, such as the hashed password and other security information

reference.source: CIS Ubuntu Linux 18.04 LTS Benchmark V2.0.1

metadata.title: Ensure permissions on /etc/group are configured
metadata.description: The /etc/group file contains a list of all the valid groups defined in the system.

reference.source: CIS Ubuntu Linux 18.04 LTS Benchmark V2.0.1

metadata.title: Ensure permissions on /etc/gshadow are configured
metadata.description: The /etc/gshadow file is used to store the information about groups that is critical to the security of those accounts, such as the hashed password and other security information.

reference.source: CIS Ubuntu Linux 18.04 LTS Benchmark V2.0.1

metadata.title: Ensure permissions on /etc/passwd- are configured
metadata.description: The /etc/passwd- file contains backup user account information.

reference.source: CIS Ubuntu Linux 18.04 LTS Benchmark V2.0.1

metadata.title: Ensure permissions on /etc/shadow- are configured
metadata.description: The /etc/shadow- file is used to store backup information about user accounts that is critical to the security of those accounts, such as the hashed password and other security information.

reference.source: CIS Ubuntu Linux 18.04 LTS Benchmark V2.0.1

metadata.title: Ensure permissions on /etc/group- are configured
metadata.description: The /etc/group- file contains a backup list of all the valid groups defined in the system.

reference.source: CIS Ubuntu Linux 18.04 LTS Benchmark V2.0.1

metadata.title: Ensure permissions on /etc/gshadow- are configured
metadata.description: The /etc/gshadow- file is used to store backup information about groups that is critical to the security of those accounts, such as the hashed password and other security information.

reference.source: CIS Ubuntu Linux 18.04 LTS Benchmark V2.0.1

metadata.title: Ensure no world writable files exist
metadata.description: Unix-based systems support variable settings to control access to files. World writable files are the least secure. See the chmod(2) man page for more information.

reference.source: CIS Ubuntu Linux 18.04 LTS Benchmark V2.0.1

metadata.title: Ensure no unowned files or directories exist
metadata.description: Sometimes when administrators delete users from the password file they neglect to remove all files owned by those users from the system.

reference.source: CIS Ubuntu Linux 18.04 LTS Benchmark V2.0.1

criterion.comment: no unowned files or directories exist

metadata.title: Ensure no ungrouped files or directories exist
metadata.description: Sometimes when administrators delete users or groups from the system they neglect to remove all files owned by those users or groups.

reference.source: CIS Ubuntu Linux 18.04 LTS Benchmark V2.0.1

criterion.comment: no ungrouped files or directories exist

metadata.title: Ensure password fields are not empty
metadata.description: An account with an empty password field means that anybody may log in as that user without providing a password.

reference.source: CIS Ubuntu Linux 18.04 LTS Benchmark V2.0.1

metadata.title: Ensure no legacy "+" entries exist in /etc/passwd
metadata.description: The character + in various files used to be markers for systems to insert data from NIS maps at a certain point in a system configuration file. These entries are no longer required on most systems, but may exist in files that have been imported from other platforms.

reference.source: CIS Ubuntu Linux 18.04 LTS Benchmark V2.0.1

metadata.title: Ensure no legacy "+" entries exist in /etc/shadow
metadata.description: The character + in various files used to be markers for systems to insert data from NIS maps at a certain point in a system configuration file. These entries are no longer required on most systems, but may exist in files that have been imported from other platforms.

reference.source: CIS Ubuntu Linux 18.04 LTS Benchmark V2.0.1

metadata.title: Ensure no legacy "+" entries exist in /etc/group
metadata.description: The character + in various files used to be markers for systems to insert data from NIS maps at a certain point in a system configuration file. These entries are no longer required on most systems, but may exist in files that have been imported from other platforms.

reference.source: CIS Ubuntu Linux 18.04 LTS Benchmark V2.0.1

metadata.title: Ensure root is the only UID 0 account
metadata.description: Any account with UID 0 has superuser privileges on the system.

reference.source: CIS Ubuntu Linux 18.04 LTS Benchmark V2.0.1

criterion.comment: root is the only UID 0 account

metadata.title: Ensure root PATH Integrity
metadata.description: The root user can execute any command on the system and could be fooled into executing programs unintentionally if the PATH is not set correctly.

reference.source: CIS Ubuntu Linux 18.04 LTS Benchmark V2.0.1

criterion.comment: directories contained in $PATH have proper permissions set

metadata.title: Ensure all users' home directories exist
metadata.description: Users can be defined in /etc/passwd without a home directory or with a home directory that does not actually exist.

reference.source: CIS Ubuntu Linux 18.04 LTS Benchmark V2.0.1

metadata.title: Ensure users' home directories permissions are 750 or more restrictive
metadata.description: While the system administrator can establish secure permissions for users' home directories, the users can easily override these.

metadata.title: Ensure all groups in /etc/passwd exist in /etc/group
metadata.description: Over time, system administration errors and changes can lead to groups being defined in /etc/passwd but not in /etc/group .

reference.source: CIS Ubuntu Linux 18.04 LTS Benchmark V2.0.1

metadata.title: Ensure no duplicate UIDs exist
metadata.description: Although the useradd program will not let you create a duplicate User ID (UID), it is possible for an administrator to manually edit the /etc/passwd file and change the UID field.

reference.source: CIS Ubuntu Linux 18.04 LTS Benchmark V2.0.1

metadata.title: Ensure no duplicate GIDs exist
metadata.description: Although the groupadd program will not let you create a duplicate Group ID (GID), it is possible for an administrator to manually edit the /etc/group file and change the GID field.

reference.source: CIS Ubuntu Linux 18.04 LTS Benchmark V2.0.1

metadata.title: Ensure no duplicate user names exist
metadata.description: Although the useradd program will not let you create a duplicate user name, it is possible for an administrator to manually edit the /etc/passwd file and change the user name.

reference.source: CIS Ubuntu Linux 18.04 LTS Benchmark V2.0.1

metadata.title: Ensure no duplicate group names exist
metadata.description: Although the groupadd program will not let you create a duplicate group name, it is possible for an administrator to manually edit the /etc/group file and change the group name.

reference.source: CIS Ubuntu Linux 18.04 LTS Benchmark V2.0.1

metadata.title: Ensure shadow group is empty
metadata.description: The shadow group allows system programs which require access the ability to read the /etc/shadow file. No users should be assigned to the shadow group.

reference.source: CIS Ubuntu Linux 18.04 LTS Benchmark V2.0.1
